Playboy Ma azine Squelches Vickers
To Sue JH Students
If ModelRaffled Off
Frank De Kuyper, the campus representative of Playboy
Magazine was authorized to issue the following statement to the
News-Letter this week:
"Playboy Magazine has given permission only to use decorations
for the dance—not raffling off of Miss Vickers and her favors.
Playboy Magazine intends to sue Roland Blantz, the Booster Club,
and the Cotillion Board if they persist in their announced policy
of raffling off this model.
Playboy Magazine further expects
cancellation of the announced policy to raffle off ,this model, and
considers the organizers of this dance to have used poor taste in
their handling of the matter."
In answer to this statement, Roland Blantz, chairman of
tonight's Playboy Dance, has stated:
"In response to Mr. DeKuyper's contention of illegality in the
case of Miss Vickers, a verbal agreement was made with Playboy
Magazine that our publicity would not pass off Miss Vickers as a
Playmate of the Month or in any way connect her with Playboy
magazine. This was the only limiting factor on our use of tile
Playboy name. We have not stated the above in the News-Letter
or in our publicity in general."
By BOB
"De Kuyper makes a dismal
Picture, Vickers' absence causes
gloom; Blantz protests. a Playboy
Stricture, Sees a lawsuit as his
doom."—(adapted from F. J.
Haydn). This was the melancholy tune sung at the announcement by Roland Blantz,
Chairman of the Playboy dance,
that Laura Vickers, controversial model hired by the Cotillion
Board for the dance, would not
be present due to pressure exerted by Playboy magazine.
No Objections From Playboy
Blantz explained that the
Cotillion Board had tried during the summer to get a PlayMate for the dance, and had
subsequently hired Miss Vickers
to act in this capacity. He stated
that at that time, Playboy Magazine had expressed no objections
to Miss Vickers' being called
"Miss Playboy," the title given
her when the controversial publication objected to the title
"Miss Playmate."

Emptied By ScareNo Bomb Located
About 200 students and emPloyees were evacuated from
Mergenthaler Hall about 3:35
P.M. Oct. 20 after a telephone
0Perator received an anonymous
Call saying that a bomb had been
Planted in the biology labs. Mr.
J. W. Peach, Associate Plant
Manager, in accordance with
University policy, requested the
evacuation and called the police.

TEP's Top Greek List
In Scholarship Poll
The scholastic standing of the
14 JHU frat,ernties has been
released by Miss Irene M. Davis,
registrar. The averages are as
follows.
TEP-6.179 (28 members) Phi
Ep-5.332 (54), Sig Ep-5.214 (33),
AEPi-5.156 (47), ZBT-4.934 (17),
Phi Sig-4.927 (60), Delta Phi4.861 (17), AD-4.838 (38). ATO4.867 (53), Phi Psi-4.473 (52),
DU-4.292 (49), Phi Gam-4.289
(51), KA-4.284 (30), Beta-4.165

(42).
The fraternity averages computed above were based on lists
of members and pledges who
were full time matriculating
undergraduates at Johns Hopkins. The lists Were submitted by
the fraternities, and have not
been verified.
The averages were based on a
10 point scale with 10 as an H.
The all men's average for the
undergraduate school is 4.956.

In an interview with a NewsLetter reporter, Miss Hubbard
complained vehemently about
undergraduates who take books
without signing the slip in the
back cover and leaving it at the
desk. "While many students are
no doubt absent-minded enough
to forget to leave the slip, I have
no doubt that many people are
deliberately doing this so that
they can keep a book as long as
they like, perhaps permanently,"
said Miss Hubbard. "If this is
done deliberately, it must be regarded as theft and a violation
of the Honor Code, in my
opinion. Since the staff is not
all eyes, it must be up to the
students to be more careful in
this matter."

AN ARTIST'S SKETCH OF THE NEW JHU EMBRYO LAB

Weather permitting, the Carnegie Institute's new ' embryology headquarters on the Homewood Campus will be ready for
occupancy in May, 1961.
Located at
.the corner of San
Martin Drive and University
Parkway, the new edifice will
incorporate many innovations
from the usual Hopkins style.
The two and one half story
building will de,viate from the
typical Georgian style of architecture prevalent on Homewood
Campus. The lab will be a modern glass-paneled structure with
outdoor patios. Architects Anderson. Becwitly and Hiable
have made liberal use of bricks

Two reasons went into the

'Secondly, it is a very attractive site for the type of building
that we want."

Many of the faculty members of

mentioned as examples. Dr.
Ebert himself studied at Hopkins
before going to the Carnegie Institute.
Also many of the Ph.D. candidates have done their research
at the Embryology lab. Research

Rush Period Ends
As 44% Of Frosh
Join Fraternities

The IFC today began discussion on the problem of fraternity housing, as it affects one of
its members, Phi Sigma Delta,
and as it could affect all of
them,
phi Sigma Delta fraternity
bought a $50,000 house on Canterbury Road last year and
moved in January, 1960. It had
been granted a permit by the
Baltimore Zoning Board. That
permit was contested by the
ImproveCanterbury-Tuscany
ment Association, the matter
being taken to court.
On the grounds that the renting of rooms, although not carried on by Phi Sigma Delta
fraternity for profit-making
purposes, is usually carried on
as a profit-making venture, the
fraternity did not meet the
specifications required by the
zoning laws for multiple-dwelling units and Phi Sig lost the
case. •
No Sleeping
The zoning laws allow the Phi
Sigs to eat and have parties in
their house; but they do not
mention anything about sleeping or living in the house. The
court, thereby, drew the inference that what was not mentioned, was not permitted. The
fraternity is appealing the case
to a higher court. As yet, the
case hasn't been listed on that

court's docket.
In the meantime, an injunction was sought . by Phi Sig's
neighbors seeking to restrain
the fraternity from using the
house until such time as a decision is made on the appeal.
The order was granted.
Temporarily, Phi Sig has rented a house on 2908 Calvert
Street which can sleep 10-15
boys. The other house has been
closed for practical purposes.
$5000 Cost
It is casting the fraternity
approximately $5000 to fight
the case and $155 per month
to lease the Calvert Street house.
The Alumni and National of Phi
Sigma Delta are footing the bill.
Recently, Kappa Alpha has
been having its troubles with
the zoning board. They had
electrical work done over the
summer and it was discovered
that their housing permit was
improper. Last week they were
zoned as a fraternity by the
zoning board, and, for the time
being, can relax.
Up To Neighbors
It was explained by Mike
Sher, spokesman for Phi Sig,
that this was possible because,
despite the Phi Sig decision, the
zoning board does not necessarily have to rule against a fraternity. In the K.A., case, no
neighbors " had complained—in

the Phi Sig case they did. He
noted that had there been protestors in the case, the Board .
probably would have ruled in
favor of the protestors.
The attornies for Phi Sig have
intimated that if any property
owner protests against any fraternity _ at Hopkins, the zoning
board would rule in favor of the
protestor. This does not apply
to any fraternity which had
owned its house since 1929, when
the zoning law was changed.

Goucherites Play
Duplicate Bridge
In Hopkins Club
Goucher College will be participating for the first time in
the Hopkins Duplicate Bridge
Club beginning with this year's
first meeting, Sunday, October
30, at 1:30 p.m. A "more cordial
atmosphere" than in past years
is expected by Director Bob
Rivkin.
All undergraduates, graduate
students, faculty members, and
their guests are invited to attend the tournaments which will
continue every Sunday at 1:30
until the end of the year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 28, 1960

Military Company Barter's 'Conflict' Changes
Begins Program Dorm Council Meeting Time
For New Pledges
Company E-15 of the National
Society of Pershing Rifles, the
National Honorary Military Society for cadets of the Basic
Course, R.O.T.C., has begun. its
Pledge program for this year.
Under the direction of P.R. 2nd
Lt. Robert L. McGill, (pledge
Officer) the pledges will drill and
study several hours a week on
their own time in order to become qualified for membership.
Those freshman intending to
pledge are cadets: Salvatore Abbratozzato, Stephen Daiger, Ronald Darone, Mark Dawber, Frederick Eustis, Peter Grossman,
Peter Kangieser, Reynold Karr,
Stephen Klavohn; Michael Koppisch, Alexander Karo, Franklin Payne, Mark Moumonier,
Jeffrey Richter, Howard Roberts,
William Stine, Ronald Sweat,
Dennis Tenley, Andrew Voskis,
Roger Wattendorf, Thomas
Weaver, George White, E. Skiller,
S. Haavak, and P. Thompson.

Y MOVIE-

The D.S.R.C. this week held
an extended debate on whether
to change its meeting time to
8:00 p.m. in order to make it
convenient for advisor Barter to
attended the meeting. Mr. Barter
had an "irreconcilable conflict"
at 7:00 p.m.
During the course of the debate several motions were considered, including one to hold
the meeting at 10:00 p.m. After
one motion had been voted upon,
one representative raised his
hand and asked plaintively,
"Would you mind telling me
what I just opposed?"

It was finally decided to hold
the meeting at 7:30 p.m. as this
would be convenient for Mr.
Barter.
Several points of controversy
from last week were also clarified. Keith Conrad read a letter
from the plant manager's office
reaffirming their determination
to "exterminate all matter in the
dorms including rats." It was
also pointed out that the hair
nets for the food service would
be necessary since "two of the
ladies in the food service wear
wigs."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER, 28,• 1960

CO-ED MAT'S ADD
FEMININE TOUCH
"I'm for co-education, but
where are the women coming
from?"
With this remark the teacher
in an undergraduate history
course began a lecture recently.
In answer to his query half a
dozen or so female voices stated,
"We are in MAT."
Puzzled expressions crossed
the faces of some of the undergraduates in the course. They
had heard of MAT before, but
besides knowing that it is connected with the Education Department, most of them probably had no idea of what it is.
MAT stands for Master of Arts
in Teaching. It is a program
designed to provide graduates of
liberal arts colleges additional
training in their field and certification to teach in secondary
schools.
Instituted At Hopkins
In an interview this week, Dr.
John Walton, Chairman of the
Department of Education and
Director of the Master of Arts
in Teaching Program, outlined
the history, scope and objectives
of the program.
Although the MAT program is
fairly new at Hopkins, having
been started in 1957; its history
goes back to 1936 when Dr.
James Conant, then the President of Harvard initiated an
MAT program at that university.
The degree to be given was
designated as a Master' of Arts
in Teaching, rather than a Master of Arts degree because it is
not a research degree as the
M.A. is, but rather a teaching
degree.
The program, however, did not
meet with much success until
after the Second World War. At
that time the Ford Foundation
became interested in it.
Program Widespread
With the Ford Foundation
supplying the Funds
-, similar
programs were started at other
universities. The number of universities that presently have
MAT - prOgrams is over thirty,
with such institutions as Harvard, Yale, Duke, Brown and
Chicago included.
In 1957 with the aid of a
grant of $275,000 from the Fund
for the Advancement of Education, Johns Hopkins initiated an
MAT program.
In 1959 an additional sum of
$841,000 was granted to continue
the program for seven years beyond the original three.

Full Responsibilities
The MAT students, on the
other hand, assume the responsibilities and duties of a fulltime teacher. They teach without any supervision and in most
cases have a full schedule of
classes. In addition they perform other functions of a regular teacher including coaching
and attending PTA meetings.
In the High School Journal of
February, 1960, an article appeared by Dr. Walton titled
"The Scholar-Teacher" in which
he set forth the purpose of the
MAT program.
In this article Dr. Walton
stated that among other reforms
needed in our secondary schools
iS "the recruil ment of more
teachers with continuing intellectual interests.
"The fallacy in teacher education had been the aSsumption
that every teacher should be a
specialist or a scholar in Education. The high schools need a
corps of scholars — linguists,
mathematicians, historians, biologists, physicists — who are
competent in the techniques of
teaching, but who continue to
be primarily interested in their
subject matter."

Esquire Was Never Like This
What's all this self-righteous indignation about?
Playboy magazine is perturbed because its good name is
being associated with a dance, the good taste of which it
questions. The magazine, through its campus representative, has threatened to bring suit if the promoters of the
dance go through with their former plans to raffle off a
young lady.
Perhaps there is a legal point involved in this case
whereby the magazine has good cause to sue; perhaps the
promoters are doing things they weren't authorized to
do. We'll let the judge—if suit is brought—decide that.
But our decision is that the whole matter is pretty
ridiculous. We can't see how Playboy can question anyone
else's good taste; and we certainly 'don't see how the
raffling off of Miss Vickers would in any way, shape, or
form, injure the good name of that worthy publication
(so well-known for• its "pent-house parties," and elite
"private clubs").

Careful Thinking
The air has cleared, feelings have calmed down a bit,
grumblings are down to a dull roar. Still, the DSRC and
its problems remain but we think that a second glance, and
a fresh outlook are in order.
The situation at the dorms is one that should provoke
a bit of careful thinking, and less 'standing up and shouting for one's rights.' And this thinking should be on the
part of the students. If you want the lack of rules, the
free 'traditional' atmosphere, the good representation, the
fine reputation, and the help and guidance (when you
ask for it) of the men on the faculty who take an interest
in you; if you want all this, then begin filling your shoes
With responsibility- and maturity.
If the majority of you feel that thinffs are not as they
should be, and such could very well be the case, then stop
complaining and grumbling and begin some action. Choose
new and more capable leaders, if necessary; outline to
Dr. Morrill what yon feel are the real problems, and what
you would like him to do about it; and especially clamp
down on the 10 or 15% of the boys in each entry who cause
all the damage, the noise, and the trouble, and spoil the
freedoms for everyone else.
Perhaps in these ways, and with more careful thinking and acting, will you tactfully arrive at the dorm atmosphere that you are seeking.

The twelve month MAT program is broken down into three
phases:
The student spends the summer months taking pedagogical
courses such as educational
psychology, and principles of
secondary school teaching.
• One semester of the academic
year is devoted to taking courses
in the student's field. While no
number of credits to be earned
is specified, the department expects the students to take a
normal amount of courses for a
first year graduate student.
Teaching Internship
The other semester is devoted
to intern teaching in a secondary
school at the salary of an uncertified teacher.
This teaching is termed an
internship Dr. Walton explained,
because it differs markedly from
the practice teaching done by
undergraduate majors in education who spend part of their
senior year practice teaching in
a high school.
The undergraduates teach under the close supervision of a
full-time teacher. They do not
have their own classes, but teach
the classes of the teachers who
observe them.

To the Editors:
The letter of Mr. Brian Henderson, pertaining to the Playboy Dance, offered a wellphrased demur to the attention
which the NEWS-LETTER has
devoted to the campaign for desegration of local restaurants.
In the respective outlooks of
the letter writer and the editors
is seen a current example of
that polarity which has been a
continuing feature of American
reform endeavors. I would call
Mr. Henderson's position the
"suppression-of-vice" approach,
while the view represented by the
editors might be called "social
gospel-humanitarian." The former has traditionally sought
the eradication of individual
"evils"—liquor, dancing, etc.; the
latter has tended to emphasize
social reforms—e.g. amelioration
of labor conditions and civil
rights — which are looked upon
as steps to the achievement of
the good society.
Theoretically, one might expect that these are but two sides
of the same coin, whereas, in
practice, they have too often
been antithetical. A classic case
was the 1899 crusade of the
evangelist, Sam Jones, to oust
his namesake, the celebrated social
reform
mayor,
Sam
"Golden-Rule" Jones, from office in Toledo largely because of
the latter's "lax" views on temperance.
I do not wish to misinterpret
Mr. Henderson's position, but the
tenor of his letter suggests to me
that he may not possess much
enthusiasm for consicous efforts
at reform of the social order.
Neither is my point to take issue
with the writer's objections to
Playboy, nor to question the extent to which it may or may not
constitute a menace to society.
However, it does seem a mistake
to disparage "the role of crusading idealists" who "go out of
their way to take action in the
matter of racial prejudice," even
if one does not himself feel
committed to participate actively in a given enterprise.
Raymond J. Cunningham

A FRAT TO REMEMBER
Every year, as we all know, the Benevolent and Protective
Order of Collegiate Fraternities awards a highly coveted prize
to the fraternity house which, in its judgment, has done the
most to promote and enhance the fraternity way of life. The
prize this year—eight hundred pounds of white putty—goes to
the Signa Phi Nothing chapter of the South Dakota College
of Dentistry and Renaissance Art.
The award this year is exceptionally richly deserved, for the
Signa Phi Nothing house is the very model of .all a fraternity
should be. It is, first of all, a most attractive house physically.
The outside walls are tastefully covered with sequins. Running
along the upper story is a widow's walk, with a widow stationed
every three feet. Moored to the chimney pot is the Graf Zeppelin.
Indoors,the house gives an impression of simple,casual charm.
The chapter room is furbished in homey maple and chintz,
with a'dash of verve provided by a carp pool three hundred feet
in diameter. A waterspout rises from the center of the pool with
the housemother bouncing on the top.
Members' rooms are gracious and airy and are provided with
beds which disappear into the wall—permanently. Each room
also has a desk, a comfortable chair, a good reading lamp, and
a catapult for skeetshooting. Kidney-shaped desks are available for kidney-shaped members.
Perhaps the most fetching feature of the house are the packs
of Marlboros stacked in heaps wherever one goes. If one wishes
to settle back and enjoy a full-flavored smoke, one needs only
to reach out one's band in any direction and pick a pack of
Marlboros—soft pack or flip-top box—and make one's self comfortable with a filtered cigarette with an unfiltered taste—that
triumph of the tobacconist's art, that paragon of smokes, that
acme of cigarettes, that employer of mine—Marlboro!

DR. FROOD'S THOUGHT FOR THE DAY:

Dear Dr. Frood: Don't you agree that every college
man has the right, in fact,the duty,to stand up and
speak out for the things he believes in? Tomorrow
I am going straight to the college president and
tell him, politely but firmly, what is wrong here—
the inferior teaching, the second-rate accommodations, the bad food. My friends think I am wrong to
do this.-What do you think?
Determined
DEAR DETERMINED: I applaud your spirit, young
man! Had I been able, I would have commended
you in a more personal letter. However, you forgot
to leave a forwarding address.

Dear Dr. Frood: What should I look for first when I
look for a wife?
Searching
DEAR SEARCHING: Her husband.

months, and vie haven't heard a word from him.
Not even a post card.Idon't want him to think I am
too demanding or overprotective, but frankly I am
worried. What should I do?
Worried Mother

in college? He's still learning how to write.

slogan: "Remember how great cigarettes used to
taste? Luckies still do." I've been sitting here for
hours, thinking, thinking, thinking, but for the'life
of me I can't remember. What should I do about
this?
Forgetful
DEAR FORGETFUL: I suggest you lean back, relax,
and light up a Lucky Strike.
I'm sure it will all come
back to you—who you are,
what you were, where you
lived, everything.

handsome, tanned, muscled, a good athlete. But I
can't get along with girls because I can never think
of anything to say. What do you suggest?
Brawny

champions, retained their undefeated record as they played
W&L to a hard-fought 8-8 tie.
This Saturday the Jays again
travel southward, to Randolph
Macon.
A fumble on the W&L 31 gave
the Generals their first opportunity to score. After marching
rapidly to the Hopkins 2 yard
line, an end sweep, gave the
home team their touchdown. A
fullback plunge got two bonus
points. .
Henry Ciccarone then led the
men from the Homewood up
field on twelve plays to score
their touchdown. The scoring
punch came on an end sweep by
Ciccarone from -the 3 yard line.
The score now 8-6, pilot Ciccarone swept right end for two
conversion points and the -first
half ended 8-8.
In the second half the Blue
Jay gridders played an outstandingly aggressive game. Determined and unyielding, they
brought the game to their opponents.
A quick kick from the W&L
two yard line placed the ball on
the 36 with first and ten for the
Jays. Ciccarone's end sweeps,
combined with fullback Skip
Leet's wedges and plunges,
brought the ball to the 4.
With the ball on the W&L
one Ciccarone elected to sweep
his right end, but in crossing the
goal, the ball was fumbled. A
quick recovery was made by
W&L on the 2.
A few minutes later Jay tailback Ciccarone hit end Derwin
Kim in the end zone for what
appeared to be a Hopkins score.
However, an illegal procedure
penalty nullified the play.
With a forth down situation
and 24 yards to go, Ciccarone

JHU Gridder drives for first
down in last weekend's clash
against W. and L.
once more caught end Kim in
the end zone; but it was ruled
that the Hopkins receiver had
stepped out of bounds.
The Generals gained possession of the ball but the W&L
attack bogged down at the Jay
25 as time ran out.
At Lexington, Va., the Blue
Jay gridders displayed an outstanding team effort. In what
appeared to be a very even game
statistically, the Jays stopped a
powerful 38 man W&L attack
with the efforts of only 19 men.
Great mention must go to veterans Norm Steketee and Jim
Kelly who both played a grueling 60 minutes of football.
By using their great depth,
the Generals were usually able
to wear down their opponents.
Scoring 9 second haf touchdowns already this year, the

W&L squad met a stubborn,
rough Hopkins team which refused to tire.
Commenting after the game,
Coach Wilson Fewster said,
"The boys played a good game.
They were tired after the contest; but I think that the Generals were more tired." "This
W&L game was one of the finest
efforts ever made by a Hopkins
team."
The Hopkins junior tailback
and standout Henry Ciccarone
ha,d the finest offensive game
of his career, as well as his usual good defensive game, rolling
up 152 yards.
As usual, the Hopkins fullbacks stood out. With Skip Leet
and Phil Sutley combining for
130 yards, the Jays had a total
offense of 277 yards and 17 first
downs. Washington & Lee gained 210 yards on the ground and
20 by passing (3 of 8) for 13
first downs.
In this exciting team accomplishment of last Saturday, we
recognize the efforts of other
reliable Hopkins players. Al
Freeland displayed his usual
fine play as an offensive end
along with Derwin Kim. Freeland again shared honors in
linebacking with. 135 lb. Leon
Poffenberger. Defensively Pat
Mahoney and John Doud both
played good games, each making a pass interception.
The Jays now boast of a
3-0-1 record and must look forward to rougher opponents and
harder work. But, this Blue Jay
team has displayed a surprising
amount of spirit and determination. With the failure of six
Varsity lettermen to return and
the loss of five freshman standouts, the men from the Homewood have met the challenge
well with team pride, desire,
and guts. The Hopkins football
team deserves outstanding credit
for a fine job done thus far.

Frank De Kuyper, the campus representative of Playboy
Magazine was authorized to issue the following statement to the
News-Letter this week:
"Playboy Magazine has given permission only to use decorations
for the dance—not raffling off of Miss Vickers and her favors.
Playboy Magazine intends to sue Roland Blantz, the Booster Club,
and the Cotillion Board if they persist in their announced policy
of raffling off this model.
Playboy Magazine further expects
cancellation of the announced policy to raffle off ,this model, and
considers the organizers of this dance to have used poor taste in
their handling of the matter."
In answer to this statement, Roland Blantz, chairman of
tonight's Playboy Dance, has stated:
"In response to Mr. DeKuyper's contention of illegality in the
case of Miss Vickers, a verbal agreement was made with Playboy
Magazine that our publicity would not pass off Miss Vickers as a
Playmate of the Month or in any way connect her with Playboy
magazine. This was the only limiting factor on our use of tile
Playboy name. We have not stated the above in the News-Letter
or in our publicity in general."

that Laura Vickers, controversial model hired by the Cotillion

be present due to pressure exerted by Playboy magazine.
No Objections From Playboy

to act in this capacity. He stated
that at that time, Playboy Magazine had expressed no objections

"Miss Playboy," the title given
her when the controversial publication objected to the title
"Miss Playmate."

complained vehemently about
undergraduates who take books

back cover and leaving it at the

Rush Period Ends
As 44% Of Frosh
Join Fraternities

The IFC today began discussion on the problem of fraternity housing, as it affects one of
its members, Phi Sigma Delta,
and as it could affect all of
them,
phi Sigma Delta fraternity
bought a $50,000 house on Canterbury Road last year and
moved in January, 1960. It had
been granted a permit by the
Baltimore Zoning Board. That
permit was contested by the
ImproveCanterbury-Tuscany
ment Association, the matter
being taken to court.
On the grounds that the renting of rooms, although not carried on by Phi Sigma Delta
fraternity for profit-making
purposes, is usually carried on
as a profit-making venture, the
fraternity did not meet the
specifications required by the
zoning laws for multiple-dwelling units and Phi Sig lost the
case. •
No Sleeping
The zoning laws allow the Phi
Sigs to eat and have parties in
their house; but they do not
mention anything about sleeping or living in the house. The
court, thereby, drew the inference that what was not mentioned, was not permitted. The
fraternity is appealing the case
to a higher court. As yet, the
case hasn't been listed on that

court's docket.
In the meantime, an injunction was sought . by Phi Sig's
neighbors seeking to restrain
the fraternity from using the
house until such time as a decision is made on the appeal.
The order was granted.
Temporarily, Phi Sig has rented a house on 2908 Calvert
Street which can sleep 10-15
boys. The other house has been
closed for practical purposes.
$5000 Cost
It is casting the fraternity
approximately $5000 to fight
the case and $155 per month
to lease the Calvert Street house.
The Alumni and National of Phi
Sigma Delta are footing the bill.
Recently, Kappa Alpha has
been having its troubles with
the zoning board. They had
electrical work done over the
summer and it was discovered
that their housing permit was
improper. Last week they were
zoned as a fraternity by the
zoning board, and, for the time
being, can relax.
Up To Neighbors
It was explained by Mike
Sher, spokesman for Phi Sig,
that this was possible because,
despite the Phi Sig decision, the
zoning board does not necessarily have to rule against a fraternity. In the K.A., case, no
neighbors " had complained—in

the Phi Sig case they did. He
noted that had there been protestors in the case, the Board .
probably would have ruled in
favor of the protestors.
The attornies for Phi Sig have
intimated that if any property
owner protests against any fraternity _ at Hopkins, the zoning
board would rule in favor of the
protestor. This does not apply
to any fraternity which had
owned its house since 1929, when
the zoning law was changed.

CO-ED MAT'S ADD
FEMININE TOUCH
"I'm for co-education, but
where are the women coming
from?"
With this remark the teacher
in an undergraduate history
course began a lecture recently.
In answer to his query half a
dozen or so female voices stated,
"We are in MAT."
Puzzled expressions crossed
the faces of some of the undergraduates in the course. They
had heard of MAT before, but
besides knowing that it is connected with the Education Department, most of them probably had no idea of what it is.
MAT stands for Master of Arts
in Teaching. It is a program
designed to provide graduates of
liberal arts colleges additional
training in their field and certification to teach in secondary
schools.
Instituted At Hopkins
In an interview this week, Dr.
John Walton, Chairman of the
Department of Education and
Director of the Master of Arts
in Teaching Program, outlined
the history, scope and objectives
of the program.
Although the MAT program is
fairly new at Hopkins, having
been started in 1957; its history
goes back to 1936 when Dr.
James Conant, then the President of Harvard initiated an
MAT program at that university.
The degree to be given was
designated as a Master' of Arts
in Teaching, rather than a Master of Arts degree because it is
not a research degree as the
M.A. is, but rather a teaching
degree.
The program, however, did not
meet with much success until
after the Second World War. At
that time the Ford Foundation
became interested in it.
Program Widespread
With the Ford Foundation
supplying the Funds
-, similar
programs were started at other
universities. The number of universities that presently have
MAT - prOgrams is over thirty,
with such institutions as Harvard, Yale, Duke, Brown and
Chicago included.
In 1957 with the aid of a
grant of $275,000 from the Fund
for the Advancement of Education, Johns Hopkins initiated an
MAT program.
In 1959 an additional sum of
$841,000 was granted to continue
the program for seven years beyond the original three.

Full Responsibilities
The MAT students, on the
other hand, assume the responsibilities and duties of a fulltime teacher. They teach without any supervision and in most
cases have a full schedule of
classes. In addition they perform other functions of a regular teacher including coaching
and attending PTA meetings.
In the High School Journal of
February, 1960, an article appeared by Dr. Walton titled
"The Scholar-Teacher" in which
he set forth the purpose of the
MAT program.
In this article Dr. Walton
stated that among other reforms
needed in our secondary schools
iS "the recruil ment of more
teachers with continuing intellectual interests.
"The fallacy in teacher education had been the aSsumption
that every teacher should be a
specialist or a scholar in Education. The high schools need a
corps of scholars — linguists,
mathematicians, historians, biologists, physicists — who are
competent in the techniques of
teaching, but who continue to
be primarily interested in their
subject matter."

Esquire Was Never Like This
What's all this self-righteous indignation about?
Playboy magazine is perturbed because its good name is
being associated with a dance, the good taste of which it
questions. The magazine, through its campus representative, has threatened to bring suit if the promoters of the
dance go through with their former plans to raffle off a
young lady.
Perhaps there is a legal point involved in this case
whereby the magazine has good cause to sue; perhaps the
promoters are doing things they weren't authorized to
do. We'll let the judge—if suit is brought—decide that.
But our decision is that the whole matter is pretty
ridiculous. We can't see how Playboy can question anyone
else's good taste; and we certainly 'don't see how the
raffling off of Miss Vickers would in any way, shape, or
form, injure the good name of that worthy publication
(so well-known for• its "pent-house parties," and elite
"private clubs").

Careful Thinking
The air has cleared, feelings have calmed down a bit,
grumblings are down to a dull roar. Still, the DSRC and
its problems remain but we think that a second glance, and
a fresh outlook are in order.
The situation at the dorms is one that should provoke
a bit of careful thinking, and less 'standing up and shouting for one's rights.' And this thinking should be on the
part of the students. If you want the lack of rules, the
free 'traditional' atmosphere, the good representation, the
fine reputation, and the help and guidance (when you
ask for it) of the men on the faculty who take an interest
in you; if you want all this, then begin filling your shoes
With responsibility- and maturity.
If the majority of you feel that thinffs are not as they
should be, and such could very well be the case, then stop
complaining and grumbling and begin some action. Choose
new and more capable leaders, if necessary; outline to
Dr. Morrill what yon feel are the real problems, and what
you would like him to do about it; and especially clamp
down on the 10 or 15% of the boys in each entry who cause
all the damage, the noise, and the trouble, and spoil the
freedoms for everyone else.
Perhaps in these ways, and with more careful thinking and acting, will you tactfully arrive at the dorm atmosphere that you are seeking.

Is Everybcdy Happy?

The twelve month MAT program is broken down into three
phases:
The student spends the summer months taking pedagogical
courses such as educational
psychology, and principles of
secondary school teaching.
• One semester of the academic
year is devoted to taking courses
in the student's field. While no
number of credits to be earned
is specified, the department expects the students to take a
normal amount of courses for a
first year graduate student.
Teaching Internship
The other semester is devoted
to intern teaching in a secondary
school at the salary of an uncertified teacher.
This teaching is termed an
internship Dr. Walton explained,
because it differs markedly from
the practice teaching done by
undergraduate majors in education who spend part of their
senior year practice teaching in
a high school.
The undergraduates teach under the close supervision of a
full-time teacher. They do not
have their own classes, but teach
the classes of the teachers who
observe them.

To the Editors:
The letter of Mr. Brian Henderson, pertaining to the Playboy Dance, offered a wellphrased demur to the attention
which the NEWS-LETTER has
devoted to the campaign for desegration of local restaurants.
In the respective outlooks of
the letter writer and the editors
is seen a current example of
that polarity which has been a
continuing feature of American
reform endeavors. I would call
Mr. Henderson's position the
"suppression-of-vice" approach,
while the view represented by the
editors might be called "social
gospel-humanitarian." The former has traditionally sought
the eradication of individual
"evils"—liquor, dancing, etc.; the
latter has tended to emphasize
social reforms—e.g. amelioration
of labor conditions and civil
rights — which are looked upon
as steps to the achievement of
the good society.
Theoretically, one might expect that these are but two sides
of the same coin, whereas, in
practice, they have too often
been antithetical. A classic case
was the 1899 crusade of the
evangelist, Sam Jones, to oust
his namesake, the celebrated social
reform
mayor,
Sam
"Golden-Rule" Jones, from office in Toledo largely because of
the latter's "lax" views on temperance.
I do not wish to misinterpret
Mr. Henderson's position, but the
tenor of his letter suggests to me
that he may not possess much
enthusiasm for consicous efforts
at reform of the social order.
Neither is my point to take issue
with the writer's objections to
Playboy, nor to question the extent to which it may or may not
constitute a menace to society.
However, it does seem a mistake
to disparage "the role of crusading idealists" who "go out of
their way to take action in the
matter of racial prejudice," even
if one does not himself feel
committed to participate actively in a given enterprise.
Raymond J. Cunningham

A FRAT TO REMEMBER
Every year, as we all know, the Benevolent and Protective
Order of Collegiate Fraternities awards a highly coveted prize
to the fraternity house which, in its judgment, has done the
most to promote and enhance the fraternity way of life. The
prize this year—eight hundred pounds of white putty—goes to
the Signa Phi Nothing chapter of the South Dakota College
of Dentistry and Renaissance Art.
The award this year is exceptionally richly deserved, for the
Signa Phi Nothing house is the very model of .all a fraternity
should be. It is, first of all, a most attractive house physically.
The outside walls are tastefully covered with sequins. Running
along the upper story is a widow's walk, with a widow stationed
every three feet. Moored to the chimney pot is the Graf Zeppelin.
Indoors,the house gives an impression of simple,casual charm.
The chapter room is furbished in homey maple and chintz,
with a'dash of verve provided by a carp pool three hundred feet
in diameter. A waterspout rises from the center of the pool with
the housemother bouncing on the top.
Members' rooms are gracious and airy and are provided with
beds which disappear into the wall—permanently. Each room
also has a desk, a comfortable chair, a good reading lamp, and
a catapult for skeetshooting. Kidney-shaped desks are available for kidney-shaped members.
Perhaps the most fetching feature of the house are the packs
of Marlboros stacked in heaps wherever one goes. If one wishes
to settle back and enjoy a full-flavored smoke, one needs only
to reach out one's band in any direction and pick a pack of
Marlboros—soft pack or flip-top box—and make one's self comfortable with a filtered cigarette with an unfiltered taste—that
triumph of the tobacconist's art, that paragon of smokes, that
acme of cigarettes, that employer of mine—Marlboro!

to be held this year on February
3 and 4. Last year nearly sixty
schools from all sections of the
country were represented.
The topic for the debating
throughout this season will be
"Resolved: That the United
States Should Adopt a Program
of Compulsory Health Insurance
for All Citizens."

Torn and Confused
Alpha Epsilon Pi (Bruce
Bogart): "I thought the rush
program was very good because
it was short. However, it has
been a very strenuous experience
because so many freshmen went
into open rushing and are emotionally torn and confused about
fraternities. I've seen six, four,
and now three week rush periods
and I think we should go back
to the four week program of last
year."
(Jim
Tau Omega
Alpha
Smith): "The - rush schedule

Too Intense
Beta Theta Pi (Tom Galinski): "The period was much too
intense. However I did like the
no contact after 3:30 and elimination of snack bar rushing. As

good. It could be longer for the

doubt at all that the pledge

Saturday is an improvement as

Sunday.",

approve of the shorter rush
period even though it was more

with the increased number of
open houses. Compliments are
in order for the cleanliness of

Prefers Second Semester
Delta Upsilon (Val Perry):
"Rushing was too short this year.
I prefer second term rushing if
the fraternities could afford it
financially. The fact that so
many frosh went into open rushing indicates that three weeks
is inadequate. We were satisfied
with the no contact after 3:30
and no snack bar regulations."
Kappa Alpha (Will Bradley):
"Since we were successful we
liked it very much. It both
helped the brothers on marks
and cut down dirty rushing.
However, many good freshmen
went into open rushing."
Open Rushing
Phi Epsilon Pi (Sanford
Levin): "The principle reason
for the large number in open
rushing is the new three week
program. Last year there were

practically no open rushers. It
should be one week longer. Perhaps the idea of an entire semester of open rushing should be
considered. The weekday open
houses were fine for the first
week but the poor attendance
thereafter made them worthless."
Phi Gamma Delta (Dick
Ryan): "The rush schedule was
much too short. It didn't give
the freshmen enough time to
choose their friends for the next
four years. I don't think we
have found the best schedule
yet—we'll have to work on it
and improve it for next year.
The elimination of snack bar
rushing was an improvement."
Very Pleased
Phi Kappa Psi (Harry Purnell):"The system this year was
pretty good—we're very pleased
in general. However, we ought
to cut out the weekday open
houses and bring back the rushing in the snack bar. Perhaps
another week of rushing would
have been advisable."

rush period was not long enough
for the freshmen to make intelligent decisions. The shortnezs
of the .rush period also resulted

DR. FROOD'S THOUGHT FOR THE DAY:

Dear Dr. Frood: Don't you agree that every college
man has the right, in fact,the duty,to stand up and
speak out for the things he believes in? Tomorrow
I am going straight to the college president and
tell him, politely but firmly, what is wrong here—
the inferior teaching, the second-rate accommodations, the bad food. My friends think I am wrong to
do this.-What do you think?
Determined
DEAR DETERMINED: I applaud your spirit, young
man! Had I been able, I would have commended
you in a more personal letter. However, you forgot
to leave a forwarding address.

Dear Dr. Frood: What should I look for first when I
look for a wife?
Searching
DEAR SEARCHING: Her husband.

Dear Dr. Frood: Our son has been in college three
months, and vie haven't heard a word from him.
Not even a post card.Idon't want him to think I am
too demanding or overprotective, but frankly I am
worried. What should I do?
Worried Mother
DEAR WORRIED: Why worry after only three months
in college? He's still learning how to write.

Dear Dr. Frood: 1 am puzzled by the Lucky Strike
slogan: "Remember how great cigarettes used to
taste? Luckies still do." I've been sitting here for
hours, thinking, thinking, thinking, but for the'life
of me I can't remember. What should I do about
this?
Forgetful
DEAR FORGETFUL: I suggest you lean back, relax,
and light up a Lucky Strike.
I'm sure it will all come
back to you—who you are,
what you were, where you
lived, everything.

Dear Dr. Frood: I am six foot five, 225 pounds,
handsome, tanned, muscled, a good athlete. But I
can't get along with girls because I can never think
of anything to say. What do you suggest?
Brawny
DEAR BRAWNY:"Me Tarzan, you Jane."

Cosmopolitan Club
Announces Party,
Banquet, Lecture
The Cosmopolitan Club has
scheduled two major meetings
for the coming two Sundays involving discussion, a party, and
a banquet. The meetings will
take place October 30, and November 6. All those interested
are invited.
On October 30, the Club will
host a lecture by Mrs. Francis
Howard, executive secretary of
the Maryland U.N. Association,
entitled "U.N. in Crises and
Challenge." Beginning at 8:00
p.m. in Levering Hall, the lecture will be followed by discussion and then a Halloween
party.
The second meeting on November 6 will begin with a banquet prepared and served by the
First Lutheran Church. Following will be a discussion on the
subject,"What kind of education
do adolescents need?," by a
panel of students, from foreign
countries, such as England,
Germany, India, and others. The
deadline for these is Wednesday,
November 2, at the YMCA or at
CHesapeake 3-2810.

recipients at the White House
meeting.
AMVETS

annually
scholarships and felowships to

deceased World War II or Korea
veterans.

Jay Spike Shoes
To Sponsor Prep
Thinclad Meeting
The 16th Annual Two Mile
Invitational High School Cross
Country meet will be held at
10:30 A.M. this Saturday, Oct. 29,
sponsored by the Johns Hopkins
Spiked Shoe Society.
Some 22 schools from Baltimore and the Middle Atlantic
regions and about 160 individuals
will compete in the race. The
race starts in front of Gilman
Hall, circles the campus by way
of Charles Street, the Art Museum San Martin Drive, and
finishes on the track.

By BILL ERTAG
Johns
Hopkins, defending
Mason-Dixon Conference
champions, retained their undefeated record as they played
W&L to a hard-fought 8-8 tie.
This Saturday the Jays again
travel southward, to Randolph
Macon.
A fumble on the W&L 31 gave
the Generals their first opportunity to score. After marching
rapidly to the Hopkins 2 yard
line, an end sweep, gave the
home team their touchdown. A
fullback plunge got two bonus
points. .
Henry Ciccarone then led the
men from the Homewood up
field on twelve plays to score
their touchdown. The scoring
punch came on an end sweep by
Ciccarone from -the 3 yard line.
The score now 8-6, pilot Ciccarone swept right end for two
conversion points and the -first
half ended 8-8.
In the second half the Blue
Jay gridders played an outstandingly aggressive game. Determined and unyielding, they
brought the game to their opponents.
A quick kick from the W&L
two yard line placed the ball on
the 36 with first and ten for the
Jays. Ciccarone's end sweeps,
combined with fullback Skip
Leet's wedges and plunges,
brought the ball to the 4.
With the ball on the W&L
one Ciccarone elected to sweep
his right end, but in crossing the
goal, the ball was fumbled. A
quick recovery was made by
W&L on the 2.
A few minutes later Jay tailback Ciccarone hit end Derwin
Kim in the end zone for what
appeared to be a Hopkins score.
However, an illegal procedure
penalty nullified the play.
With a forth down situation
and 24 yards to go, Ciccarone

JHU Gridder drives for first
down in last weekend's clash
against W. and L.
once more caught end Kim in
the end zone; but it was ruled
that the Hopkins receiver had
stepped out of bounds.
The Generals gained possession of the ball but the W&L
attack bogged down at the Jay
25 as time ran out.
At Lexington, Va., the Blue
Jay gridders displayed an outstanding team effort. In what
appeared to be a very even game
statistically, the Jays stopped a
powerful 38 man W&L attack
with the efforts of only 19 men.
Great mention must go to veterans Norm Steketee and Jim
Kelly who both played a grueling 60 minutes of football.
By using their great depth,
the Generals were usually able
to wear down their opponents.
Scoring 9 second haf touchdowns already this year, the

W&L squad met a stubborn,
rough Hopkins team which refused to tire.
Commenting after the game,
Coach Wilson Fewster said,
"The boys played a good game.
They were tired after the contest; but I think that the Generals were more tired." "This
W&L game was one of the finest
efforts ever made by a Hopkins
team."
The Hopkins junior tailback
and standout Henry Ciccarone
ha,d the finest offensive game
of his career, as well as his usual good defensive game, rolling
up 152 yards.
As usual, the Hopkins fullbacks stood out. With Skip Leet
and Phil Sutley combining for
130 yards, the Jays had a total
offense of 277 yards and 17 first
downs. Washington & Lee gained 210 yards on the ground and
20 by passing (3 of 8) for 13
first downs.
In this exciting team accomplishment of last Saturday, we
recognize the efforts of other
reliable Hopkins players. Al
Freeland displayed his usual
fine play as an offensive end
along with Derwin Kim. Freeland again shared honors in
linebacking with. 135 lb. Leon
Poffenberger. Defensively Pat
Mahoney and John Doud both
played good games, each making a pass interception.
The Jays now boast of a
3-0-1 record and must look forward to rougher opponents and
harder work. But, this Blue Jay
team has displayed a surprising
amount of spirit and determination. With the failure of six
Varsity lettermen to return and
the loss of five freshman standouts, the men from the Homewood have met the challenge
well with team pride, desire,
and guts. The Hopkins football
team deserves outstanding credit
for a fine job done thus far.
